text: Duft kaffe ristet malt karamel smag kaffe ristet malt kaffe chokolade kant lidt grøn kaffe svag citrus

From can at the Hoppy Pub, Thessaloniki. Clear dark amber - copper to brown color with light beige head. Roasted malty aroma, heavy coffee, green coffee, hop notes, grass, veggie, bread. Light sweet and heavy bitter taste. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.

47,3 cl can @ home, batch #004
Aroma has mocha coffee, jalopenos, hops, nuts and chocolate. Flavour has cold coffee, hops, jalopenos and some chocolate. Lingering and tickling hops in the finish with some semi-dark chocolate. A bit messy but good anyway.
Tap at Flora. Brown with ample head and lacing. Coffee, chocolate liqueur. Dry and refined yet still flavorful. Best beer Ive had in a while.

Corps brun à reflets verts; mousse ivoire soutenu, assez serrée, avec bulles de tailles diverses. Houblons très présents, café doux; une certaine rondeur. Très savoureuse (umami); des épices. Très équilibrée, très fine.

Poured into a mug, the appearance was a murky brown color with a fingers worth of white foamy head that held and dissipated at a good pace. Lace clung effectively.
The aroma had some sweet and roasty pecans, mild cake, milk chocolate, sweet dough, some coffee beans, a touch of vanilla and had some earthy bitter hops at the end.
The flavor blended all of this fairly nice. Sweet to roasty to bitter and clenching the aftertaste pretty nice. Mild sweet and bitter sort of finish.
The palate was about medium on the body with a good sessionability about it. Carbonation felt good. ABV felt good.
Overall, pretty good brown ale that I could have again for me, but I didnt get all of those extra hoppy notes that they said they put in this.
Tap @ Muted Horn, Berlin - dark brown color, off-white head. taste is nuts, toffee, coffee, roasted malts. very intense, very balanced. dry finish. a brown ale like it should be.

1 pint can from middle of 2016. Pours a hazy brown shade with white froth. Aroma is of floral and grassy hops but not fruity in nature, and some malt - dough, and bread. There are very faint notes of coffee in the aroma - perhaps due to the age of the can - which are not too prominent. Taste is exact opposite of aroma, strongly dominated by the roasted Kenyan coffee, over biscuity and bready, flavours of the malt, but next to no hops flavours at all! Mouthfeel is a bit thin and watery, reflective of the rather weak underlying brown ale, which manages to stay afloat solely by virtual of the dominant coffee flavours.

Draught at Kød & Bajer. Low fluffy white lasting head. Pitch black body Sweet cocoa coffee caramel aroma. Pretty bitter flavor with cocoa coffee and caramel. Low carbonation. Long finish. Too bitter in my opinion.

Can at home. Pours dark brown with a big off-white head. Aroma has citrus and coffee. Taste has interesting features for a brown ale. Some citrus, espresso, chocolate and roasted malts. Quite a weird combination but still quite well balanced. Fresh and light on mouth but not watery or too light palate for the style. Impressive.
On tap at hopahplic. Deep copperish red colour, small brown head. Nose is strong coffee. Taste is steong coffee. Cp-550. Too bitter for a brown ale.
473ml can. Dark brown with beige head. Caramel malts, piney hops. Long bitter finish, medium sweet.

Tap at Brodys. Dark brown with beige head. Lots of ground coffee, dry herbs, caramel, dry nutty notes, earthy. Quite dry but some nice aromas. Light sweet and medium bitter. Medium bodied with dry watery feel.
Sampled at Brodys. Clear caramel pour with a thin tan head. Notes of fresly roasted coffee, citrus and piney hops, roasted malts, light metallic bitterness. Nice coffee brew.

Can from Torridon Convenience Stores, Catford. Brown pour with a fluffy beige head. Nose of caramel malt, raisin, smoke, toffee, a little coffee. Flavours of coffee, dried fruit, toffee. Bitter kick in the finish. Good stuff.

Can. Pours dark brown with foamy tan head. Aroma has coffee, fruits and roasted malt. Taste has some fruitiness, a lot of coffee, with roasted maltiness. Nicely bitter and even sweet. Soft and tasty. Very good coffee beer!

1pt can at home from De Caigny, Belgium. Nose is dried fruits, chocolate, roasted malt. Body is clear brown, head is big, beige, creamy rocky, mostly lasting, excellent lacing. Aroma is tons of mild roasted coffee, dried fruits, milk chocolate. Medium sweet, medium to heavy bitter. Finish is long lasting roasty coffeeish then hoppy heavy bitter, light alcohol warmth. Medium to full body, slick texture, medium carbonation. Easy dessert beer, strong flavor, very tasty, bit out of balance but I dont mind, one of my best coffee beer Ive ever drunk, great one.
Can from Alko. Dark clear brown with medium head. Coffee. Dry roasted bitterness.

473 ml can @ home. Batch #004.
Pours clear copper color with a large head. Aroma has evident coffee and caramel malts, some dry malts and hay. Flavor is coffee, bitter malts, subtle bread notes and some hop tones. A bit thin body but otherwise okay.
3424

10/IV/17 - 1Pt. can from Bierhalle Deconinck (Vichte) @ home - BB: n/a, batch 2 (2017-438) Thanks to Erwin for sharing the can!
Clear dark amber beer, creamy irregular yellowish head, pretty stable, adhesive, leaving some lacing in the glass. Aroma: very hoppy, some tropical fruit, sweet malty notes, some biscuit malts, but mainly very hoppy. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: hoppy start, soft bitterness, fruity, sweet malts, caramel. Aftertaste: soft roast, bit sweet, bitter hops, some tropical fruits, hint of coffee, but not much to be honest. And I dont drink or like coffee, so theres really not a lot in it...

Tap at Osteria del Borgo (Rome-Italy). Caramel color quite clear with amber highlights, creamy foam with proper retention. Nose: aroma of rhum, peat, burnt chops. Mouth: it feels like drinking burnt grains...really. Bitterness balances the overall. Tasty.

(Evil Twin Wet Dream) One pint can at home, served into a tumbler, ABV 6%
Brown colour on the body, clear, with a good sized beige head, thick and with good retention.
Aroma of coffee, toffee, green peppers, coffee grounds.
Taste of coffee, caramel, toffee.
Medium body, good carbonation.
Good.
9/24/16. On tap at Growler Country. Brown pour with a small khaki head. Light citrus aroma, coffee, nutty, hint of chocolate. Coffee flavor, citrus, nutty, some chocolate. Not bad.
Bottle. Brown. Chocolate and coffee dominates. Medium body with a smooth pleasant flavour.

Can. Pours with a considerable amount of fluffly light brown foam. Color is very attractive very dark red. Aroma is rich and dense and has dark chocolate or cocoa, marshmallow, mixed nuts, rye bread. Palate is perfectly balanced and is not too oily or dry. Taste has slight bitterness and a surprising herbal taste which is like cough drops mixed with Jägermeister. Additionally theres hops (the bitterness) and some "ale"-style malt making up the body. Surprisingly I taste no coffee, even though its supposed to have it. Theres a perfect balance of sweetness and bitterness. The taste is more complicated than what I could describe, but its difficult to pick up flavours. Its a very good beer though and I would definitely buy it again. Full and rich and even small amounts make you satisfied already. Again an outstanding beer from Evil Twin.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2017 Gran bel aspetto, marrone con riflessi rossi. Schiuma beige a grana fine di buona persistenza. Aroma molto interessante per la complessa nota di spezie e agrumi, su base di malto e caramello. Al palato complessa, corpo leggero e beverina, nota tostata con netta amarezza, la nota di caffè c?è ben presente. Una birra interessante per come sono equilibrati ma intensi i sapori dolci e la parte amara ed erbacea. Carbonazione medio bassa.

Can. Brown color with off-white head. Aroma has citrus, grass and dark malt. Taste is malty with quite long somewhat bitter and only a little sweet aftertaste. Flavors of dark malt, citrus, coffee, dark chocolate, nuts.

Dark brown, muddy colour with a thick, creamy tan head. Malty and very sweet aroma, brown sugar, light syrup. Taste has malts at first, then turns into a more hoppy finish. Light bitterness. Some diluted black coffee in the aftertaste. Medium body with medium carbonation, ok mouthfeel. Its nice but I dont really like the coffee here.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2017 500ml can (Bierfox, Riga) (3:3:4:3:7=2.0)
Can - cant see whats coming out - ooops, its shitty bits. 2 glasses clear, third was cruddy. Aroma from cruddy one was very chilli pods and green beans, from clear pours was pure runner beans. Even tastes of runner beans. Wateryish, and with quite high carbonation, but that ends up soft and moussey, not unpleasant at all. Finish is again beany. Terrible brew. Wet dream? More like Wet Blanket! Drinking side-by-side with Martins homebrew /Brown Your Sorrows/ brown ale (15 months old, though never intended to be aged), and even though Martin considered that to be a bit sub-par, it makes this taste like a total diaster.
Rerate of: Tap (Sori Taproom, Helsinki) (4:4:4:3:9=2.4)
Beany aroma. Dark, redish glints. Beany taste too. Stale coffee finish. Tastes a bit watered down too. Pretty crappy. Iron joins the beany coffee in the finish.
Can at home. Dark amber brown, tan head. Nose is sweet caramel, coffee, light roast, quite some pine and citrus hops. Tastes coffee, burnt caramel, citrus hops, roast. Could use some more body.
Tap at sori taproom, helsinki. Dark brown color, tanned head. Aroma has roasted notes, coffee, some hops. Nice roasty and coffee on taste, hoppy end. Little bit too hoppy maybe but good anyway.

Cannette achetée à La Mise En Bière - De couleur brune acajou avec une belle mousse beige qui marque bien le verre et tient longtemps - Au des aromes de café, de brownie, de biscuits, de fruits rouges, les houblons sont bien présent, légèrement citroné et herbacé, jaime le profil du malt et du café - En bouche toujours ce café, les malt sont plus masqué par les houblons quau nez, mais bien présent quand même biscuit, Brown malt, les houblons sont bien résineux et herbacé - Corp moyen, amertume moyenne, carbonation correcte, lisse, final café résineux amère - Superbe combinaison brown ale houblonnée et café

can @ home
clear dark brown, brown head
coffee, resin, balsamic, honey, raw licorice
cream, toffee, very herbaceous, coffee bean
herbaceous aftertaste

Coppery brown with a light tan head. Aroma is primarily coffee. Bitter, bitter, bitter. Hop intensity fights with the dark malts and coffee. Too astringent for my likings - would be more interesting if done in the London style brown ale.

An ok brown ale. Aroma was pretty weak. Notes of coffee and toffee but not very strong. Pour was a nice medium brown with a thin off white film for a head. Taste wasnt bad. A little weak. Coffee and bitter hops are all I could taste. Very hoppy and bitter for a brown ale. Light mouth feel and bitter hoppy finish. The coffee and hops did not go well together in my opinion. Nice carbonation.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Tap at Olhus Kopenhavn, Helsinki. Colour is clear light brown with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Nuts, chocolate, some hops and roasted malts. Pretty nice.

A small taste (can) @ Alko press tasting. Pours clear deep brown with a medium off-white head. Aroma is some malts with loads of coffee. Flavor is nutty malts with coffee and a hoppy finish. A bit too much coffee for the light body, but still pretty good.
$3.00 pint can from Wine Warehouse. Pours lighter brown with a soft tan head. Aroma of pine, coffee, caramel. Flavor is caramel malts, pine, brown leaves, coffee, earth. Good.

A dark brown beer, a head is medium and light beige. Aroma has strong and fresh coffee, some sweetness and hint of citrusfruits. Taste has coffee, some roastiness, also nice citrucy bitterness. Medium bodied. Strong coffee thats ok for me.

355 ml bottle. Pours a hazy mahagony with an off-white head. The aroma is hoppy with pine and light lemony. Medium body with a light to medium bitterness and a low carbonation. The taste is again hoppy, earthy with some grapefruits and lightly malty - very lightly roasted, bready. Overall a decent beer but I do not get the coffee whatsoever.

can, dark amber/brown, hazy, off white frothy head,

hoppy, lime, floral, lightly malty. 
moderate bitterness, light sweeteness, medium body,

Can from Ales by Mail. Pours hazy red-brown with a thin off-white head. Aromas of coffee, toffee, faint chocolate and citrus. Something metallic I often get with coffee beers. Taste follows this pattern. A little thin, wouldve liked a richer mouthfeel to it. Light linger of coffee.

Decent aroma - herbal, hoppy, not too strong with a lot of coffee and a bit of malts. Not too complex, but very pleasing. Taste is lightly bitter, rather dry with a distinct coffee flavour. Decent drinkability - although Im not a big fan of coffee in beer recently this works out well (although at the finish the coffee doesnt feel great). More than alright as long as brown ale is concerned.
Draught @ Sori Taproom. Pours mahogany color with a thin white head, lasting. Aroma is caramel, fruits and coffee. Flavor is coffee, dark fruity notes, toffee notes. really nice!

On tap at Twisted Jimmys. Roasted toasted malts, caramel. Light hop nose. Dark brown clear with creamy beige head. Medium body with medium carbonation. Middle-of-the-road brown ale, with mild nutty bitter finish and smooth nutty after.

Draught @ Sori Taproom. 
Poured mahogany color with a thin but lasting white head. 
Caramel, coffee notes, some fruity notes. 
Flavor has coffee, dark fruity notes, toffee notes. Mild smooth, good drinkability.

Can 1 pint (Beergium? Alko?)
Copper, nut brown color, small steady beige head, lace. Coffee beans, rye bread, citrus in the nose. Medium-bodied. Coffeish, citrus, ryeish maltyness. Not so much toastyness and/or caramalt as you could expect from brown ale, so flavourwise this is closer to "coffee amber ale".

(Keg at Sori Taproom, 20170303) The beer poured deep ruby red and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had caramel and sweetness. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, caramel, pine, grass and bitterness. Aftertaste had hops, biscuits and bitterness. A rather pleasant brown ale with dry finish.

Tap IPH. Slight coffee aroma. Lighter than the look of coffee. Looks like iced tea. Its coffee all round, cant taste any beer here. Some co2, tho. Coffee all the way, mama. Many of these coffee beers are so coffee over the top all the time. So whats the difference between this and the other evil twin of the same name, go figger.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
On keg at Ushers. 
Appearance - a bit cola and thin fawn head.
Nose - hazelnuts and burnt coffee.
Taste - more of the same. 
Palate - close to medium bodied with a crunchy texture and a long dry crunchy finish. 
Overall - a bit dominated by the coffee so it my thing.

appearance: dark cola brown, lots of tiny floaties create a haze under a creamy light tan head shrinking to a collar with minimal lacing.  aroma: 	toasted nuts, wet grass, pita bread, cola, bright coffee.  taste: 	burnt caramel, light brown sugar, toasted nuts, roasted espresso beans, hint of cola.  finish: clean, smooth, just a hint of roasty bitterness. notes: 	Now THIS is a beer. First Evil Twin beer I havent thought "meh" about. Well-balanced; coffee is prominent but doesnt overpower and isnt too acidic. Nice. Tallboy from Quench.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Browny clear. Piney hops on nose, malty, some citrus. Med light bodied easy. Well bittered. Bit light, but tasty brew.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

Very nice deep brown coloured body with a thick, three centimetre tall tan head with a light brown glow. Aroma of light coffee, roasted malt, raisins, pit fruits, apricots and a bit of malt and earth - a touch of alcohol, too. Medium-bodied; Strong roasty flavour at first with the coffee and earth very noticeable, along with some grain, toffee, caramelised sugars, prunes and a bit of light spices. Aftertaste shows some mellow sugars with a hint of earthy and meaty flavours and the coffee that shows well. After that, there isnt much there - and for the style, about right. Overall, one of the better browns of course, but that isnt saying much. A good beer, if nothing else, and much higher rated than should be, due to the label on the front. I sampled this 50 cL (one pint) can purchased from Liqour Outlet in Boonton, New Jersey on 26-November-2016 for US$1,99 sampled at home in Washington on 27-February-2017. 

Batch #001 at 18h33 printed at bottom of can.

Aroma: bad quality coffee, toast, bread, caramel
Taste: light sweet, light sour, bad quality coffee, toast, caramel, bread
Brown pour with a nice tight beige head, quite a few tiny little floaters throughout. Coffee and caramel aromas, taste is similar, biter coffee, a little sweetness from the malt, long bitter finish

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, NYC, USA. Balanced, high quality product with dominating, slightly sweet coffee. Some slightly sweet malts can be detected.

Hazy bronw/orange with some particles floating around and a small off white head. Aroma is strong espresso with some toasted malts. Flavor is same nice strong coffee with a hint of caramel and some lemony hops. Medium to light mouthfeel with a nice acidic coffee note lingering at the end.

Bottled (backlog). Brown colour, mediumsized beige head, which leaves some lace. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, mild roasted notes as well as some nutty and mild floral and wooden notes. Flavour is caramel, toffee, coffee,chocolate, mild nutty notes as well as some floral and wooden notes. Nice mellow bitterness in the finish.

Pours dark brown, with a big white head and sticky lacing. Aroma is lots of coffee. Taste is dominated by coffee too, with roasted malts and some cocoa. Smooth and creamy, with a gentle carbonation and a very pleasant coffee-bitter mouthfeel. Lovely ale, very tasty. For coffee lovers.

Can from Beergium. Dark brown color, beige head. Bitter taste with nuts, roasted malts, toffee, a bit of hops, coffee and a bit of chocolate. Bitter finish with roasted malts, chocolate, toffee, coffee and nuts. Very nice brown ale.
Aroma and taste of coffee and sweetness. Good bitterness that fills the mouth for a long time. Follow me @ Kung av öl @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.

Pint can, stamped batch #001 with no accompanying date stamp. Clear mahogany with an inch of spongy foam. Nose is spicy caramel, light coffee and a hint of green onion. Front taste of Sugar Babies candy turns to earthy bread, green herb, iced tea with lemon and a finish of mild pepper and coffee. Light-medium bodied with medium carbonation and a drinkable balance.

Can at Bottlecraft, Hanley. Pours a brown colour with a medium beige head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, some dark fruits, slight coffee, a little orange, grapefruit and subtle caramel. Taste of chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, some grapefruit, orange, slight dark fruits, a little pine and subtle caramel. Medium bodied and moderate carbonation. A dry, roasted, citrus hop bitterness in the finish. Good malt presence of chocolate, slight fruit and roastiness but further through, tasty and bitter citrus and pine. Expected a lot from this brewery and got a lot from this great beer. Very enjoyable for a style Im not really a big fan of.
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer. Mega Brown Ale. Karmel, orzechy, fajna goryczka. Chyba lepszego w wydaniu amerykańskim nie piłem.
Canned. Hazy brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, hops, coffee, citrus and caramel.
// Beeroda.hu Tasting Sessions @ Budapest 2016. Pours dark brown with a medium sized off-white head. Aroma of coffee, caramel, citrus and was slightly nutty.

Torst: pours brown with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, light citrus, coffee. Taste is bitter for a brown but it does not get into brown ipa territory. Coffee present but does not take over. Earthiness and caramel. An interesting and tasty brown ale.

16oz can from Beer Bazaar in Hainesville. Brown pour with a beige head leaving a lot of streaky lacing. Aroma has big coffee, plus cocoa and some caramel with some faintly sour malts. Taste is of roasty coffee, sweet light cocoa, some caramel malts and something lemony or a touch sour. The nose and taste are a bit thin. Lighter than medium bodied with little alcohol presence. The blend is ok and the carbonation is solid. Finishes vaguely sweet, and not too long. Shrug? Nothing special about this one. There is promise, but without more depth, it turned out to be not too much. 13.4
Dark brown body with a medium brown head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, malt. Taste is sweet and light bitter. Watery texture, light body, soft carbonation, bitter chocolate taste.

5th November 2016High Wycombe House Warming. Thanks to Wingman for the can. Hazy amber beer, good cream colour head. Palate is airy and semi dry, reasonable fine carbonation. Some light malt cream in the otherwise not very brown malts. Bitterish floral mid. Decent fruits but also quite bitter. Light floral bitter finish. Bitter linger. Pretty bloody bitter for a Brown Ale.

Can 500 ml, ABV 6%, Batch #001. Pours nut brown with medium off-white head. Aroma is grass, coffee, citrus, some pine, resin, lime, spices. Taste is pine, coffee, grass, citrus, lime, some wood, light salt, roasted cereals, leather, spices. Beautiful beer!
Can. Amber brown with cream top. Light aroma of hops and espresso coffee. Sweet with hopy notes with malts and coffee prevaling.
Leicht trübes dunkelbraun mit reichlich Schaum. Malzig, leicht fruchtig, etwas Zitrus, Espresso, würzig, leicht bitter.

16oz can. Pours a light, red-tinged brown with a medium beige head. Aroma is sweet malt, citrusy fruit, a little roast, some coffee, a hint of spice, citrus, and earthy hops. Taste is lightly roasted malt, coffee, toast, and earthy spice. Some sweetness before a bitter finish of coffee and earthy hops. Light-medium body. Soft carbonation. Thin, somewhat watery mouthfeel.

Clear, dark brown colored, small off white to beige head, not very lasting. Aroma is of malt, some caramel, bit toasty, strong coffee beans. Taste is medium sweet malt, bit toffee, some bready and light nutty notes, chocolate, light spice, strong coffee beans, coffee finish, medium coffee bitterness. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, creamy. 
(bottle, Bierhalle Deconinck, Vichte)
16 ounce CaN .. Brown coffee.. Medium foam .. Peppers, coffee, brown malt .. Mouth is a bit light, grungy finish .. . . It was like stirring a paint bucket
Pint night at Pazzos. Aroma of coffee and little else. Taste was strangely watery in my opinion.

Can from Beergium. Aroma is mildly roasted dark malt, potent coffee, cocoa, hoppy notes, nuts, mild hint of spice. Flavour is light sweet and medium bitter. Body is medium. Lovely Coffee Brown Ale, lots of potent coffee, delicious.

November 2016 - Can share at Theydons High Wycombe Tasting. Thanks Dave! As Evil Twin Wet Dream. Pours amber brown, still and clear with a foamy off-white head. Aroma is ashy, dark chocolate. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is chocolate, plum, ashy and a little floral, salty. Nice chocolatey vibes, but not as exciting as the name suggests. (3.6)

Piana obfita, żółta, średnio trwała, utrzymuje się w postaci chmurki. Barwa brązowa w herbacianym wydaniu, klarowna. W aromacie faktycznie sporo kawy, karmelu, suszonych owoców, miodu gryczanego, świerku, żywicy a nawet cytrusów. W smaku półsłodkie, lekkie, czuć dokładnie to samo i dokładnie w tej samej kolejności, co w zapachu. Goryczka średnia, ziołowa. Wysycenie średnie do niskiego.

Chyba najlepsze Brown Ale jakie piłem - kawa, karmel, susz... Jest odrobina słodyczy, sporo chmielu i słodu... Fajne!

Can at Gambrinus. Pours a deep brown with a small beige head. Lots of coffee and cacao on the nose. Clean, with more coffee and bit of green pepper on the palate. Thin body. Roasty finish that lingers.

Pours a copper with a light khaki well-retaining head. Faint coffee nose with a medium roast malt coming through more prominently. Thicker, cottony mouthfeel. Drinks like a Stone Arrogant Bastard with coffee.
16 oz can. Red brown with a khaki head and spotty lacing. Light roast coffee, wet stone, a little earthy and roasted malt aromas. Light coffee flavor with a dry minerally aftertaste. Medium body.

Keg at Omnipollos Hat, Stockholm, Sweden, Thursday 17th November 2016   Brown in colour with a touch of clarity, a reddy brown ruby glint at the bottom. Really coffee and plenty of fresh green hops, quite hoppy burps. Like this, it?s a great brown ale given a big shot of coffee.  A8 A4 T8 P4 Ov16 4.0

500ml can shared @sklepzpiwem.pl. Strong aroma of coffee with some xmas cookies in the background. Pours black brown with off white head. Taste is extremely coffee-ish - tastes almost like a cold brew coffee. Perfect drink for any coffe lovers. Rather light bodied. Very interesting and tasty beer that you would easily drink in sessions - as long as youre a coffee freak :)

Deep rich brown color, slightly caramel. Thick foam lets the beer breathe its aroma. Coffee smell comes through which Im not a fan.Good upfront taste, but too much coffee for my liking. Good balance, but not my style.
Can @ home, From Kihoskh. Clear brown pour with a frothy head. Notes of roast, light cocoa, some vanilla, freshly ground coffee and some nuts.
Can. Pours hazy brown with a small white offwhite head. Stale hops, light metal, citrus, orange, malt, caramel. Taste is stale hoppy, malty, toast, caramel, orange.

Draft sample at Growler Country escaping Orlando from hurricane Matthew. Really flavorful brown ale that definitely had an American hop bill giving it a decent kick of bitterness plus the mellow malt and coffee. Tasty.

16 oz can.
Clear but very dark brown body topped with a durable beige head.
Aroma: coffee tinged dark roasted grains.
More coffee in the flavor with some light burnt toast and burnt bean notes.
Smooth medium full body with medium carbonation

A coffee American Brown Ale. Not bad, but I think the hops get in the way of the coffee brown ale. Too hop bitter. Not bad. Body is super smooth except for lingering hop bitterness. Hop aroma gets in the way off the coffee and brown ale characteristics too. Ill still drink it.. Would have been waaay better as a regular brown/nut brown ale.
Can. Pours dark brown with a medium sized off-white head. Aroma of coffee, caramel, citrus and was slightly nutty. Flavor of roasted coffee, caramel, nuts, chocolate and had a touch of citrus.

Can. Clear dark brown, lasting beige froth. Roasted malt and light coffee aroma, piney hops. Flavour adds a little chocolate. Finishes hopppy bitter. Lasting aftertaste, well balanced and rather tasty for the style.

50cl can from beermerchants. Color is dark copper to brown. Head is medium and beige. Light sweetness, medium bitterness. Medium thin body. Aroma is cacao, roasted, coffee, light chocolate, nuts, pepper, orange.
Can.Black colour with small beige head.Aroma is mild roasted with coffee flavor and hint of spices aswell,light carbonation and even some cocoa nuts aswell,medium body and soft mild finish.

Tallahassee, Fl - on tap at Growler Country. Dark brown, khaki colored head, light lacing. Aroma of light chocolate, some nuttiness. Coffee, top soil, chocolate. Thickish mouthfeel. Nice chalky mouthfeel. Very enjoyable.
Aroma is nutty malts, coffee and mild chilies. The flavor is coffee, malts, mild nuttiness, chilies and a mix of slight sourness, heat and mild sweetness in the finish.

Can. Archer Road Beer Stop, Sheffield. 6.0%. Clear, deep copper colour. Thin, foamy, lasting, clingy, dirty beige head. Nose is not what I was expecting! Grapefruit and peach hop. Some chocolate coated toffee malts. Earthy coffee bean. Some praline. Tease has a good mix of earthy, coffee bitterness, and nutty, cocoa sweetness. Light to medium body. Soft carbonation. The hop bitterness comes through and dominates the finish. Mad as you like, and really good.

Dark amber, clear, covering lace. 
Full body, flavorful, long and bitter finish. 
Very bitter, crisp. 
Coffee flavor predominates, rather simple taste. 
Doesn't add up to much. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark cola brown with a medium head of creamy off white foam. Aroma of fresh roasted coffee. Light carbonation with plenty of lacing and a medium body. Smooth roasted malt taste with some coffee flavor and a light hop bite. The coffee is noticeable but not overpowering. Fairly enjoyable.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

0,44L can bought at the Bottle Shop Hong Kong.
Appearance: Pours a clear dark brown colour with thin to medium off-white head.
Aroma: Nutty, coffee beans, caramel, toasty. With notes of spice, raisin and citrus.
Taste: Complex taste with cocoa and citrus bitterness. The bitterness is quite sharp when swallow. There is some sweet caramel and malt sweetness as well.
Palate: Quite a light body of brown ale. Smooth texture with cocoa, caramel and bitter hop aftertaste. Medium carbonation.
Overall: A nice blend of brown ale with coffee. a good mix of bittersweet flavour> very balanced and all-rounded.

Smelled hoppy at first but then almost exclusively of coffee...fairly light smell though....taste is also of coffee but lighter mouthfeel than expected...hardly any depth...over time it tastes a bit sweeter and better...was dry at first...now a good mix of bittersweet ....not really a wet dream but it doesnt piss the bed either

Pours clear deep mahogany with medium tall off-white head. Aroma of hazelnut, coffee, caramel, citrus. Taste is mild coffee bitter with a fairly rich citrus notes. Light and smooth body with soft carbonation.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, Copenhagen - dark brown pour with beige head. Roasted and toasted malty with a prominent coffee aroma and taste, some roasted coffee, cocoa, caramelic notes, nice hoppy backing, roasted finish. Very nice!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can from Brewcraft. Pours a cloudy maroon-brown with a medium creamy fizzy tan head. Smells of nutty brown ale, lots of roasty notes as it warms up, acidic roast coffee, light raisin bread, lightly to moderately bitter and herbal. Taste starts as acidic roast coffee, lightly grassy then becomes quite bitter, stony and somewhat watery. Nice aroma, nutty and roasty. Taste is less interesting, coffee more acidic and less roasted, tapers off quickly. Coffee could be more forward, but nice blend of nutty ale with bitter coffee.

Tallboy can from Brewcraft at home. Translucent dark caramel brown with off white head. Aroma is soggy hops with some coffee and nutty roastiness. Taste is acidic coffee bitterness with nutty malt. Very bitter for a brown ale but not quite coffee, very sharp. Lasting bitter tingle. Not bad, big flavor, but wouldnt get again.
A cloudy brown pour from a 16oz can. The nose is a dry, nutty coffee. The flavor in the mouth extends that hazelnut sweetness and a touch of roast coffee. Its very quaffable.

Can (6.0% ABV) from Bottle Baron. Hazy brown/ruby body with a thick beige head. Lively carbonation. Faint lacing. Aroma of earth, toffee, dried leaves and creme brûlée topping. Flavour of black pepper, caramel and bitter coffee. Medium body with a frothy mouthfeel. Lively fizz. Quite harsh and peppery and not particularly welcoming. Lacks warmth and sweetness. Disappointing.

16oz can at Cock & Bowl. Poured a medium brown color with a small white head. Aroma was roasted malts, caramel malts. Aroma started smelling a touch green, but as it warmed, it just had a slight pressed coffee character.

2015 BJCP Category: 30A Spice/Herb/Vegetable (base style: 19C American Brown Ale)
AROMA: Espresso, pine/resin and citrus. Plenty of brown malt. 8/12APPEARANCE: Murky rusty brown/mahogany. Moderate tan foam; trace lacing. 2/3FLAVOR: Brown/amber malt presence throughout, though not especially sweet. Consistent earthy/spicy sensation from hops. Espresso flavor emerges as it goes down and is quite spicy (not quite jalapeno-like, but close). Flavors do blend, though the base brew doesnt seem to be enhanced much by the espresso. 12/20MOUTHFEEL: Medium body; fairly high carbonation. Smooth. Brief coffee aftertaste fades away cleanly. 4/5OVERALL IMPRESSION: Average brown ale with a little coffee bonus flavor. Fine, but not worth the premium price. 6/10TOTAL SCORE: 31/50DISCLAIMER: The author is not a certified BJCP judge; therefore, this score sheet is not necessarily indicative of proper BJCP judging techniques and protocol. The author is grading to 2015 BJCP Guidelines in order to prepare for examination.
Can. Brown color with a medium head. Light roasted coffee aroma. Dark caramel flavor. A bit oxidized/stale. Coffee flavor is a bit like 4 hour gas station brew. Slightly bitter.

Can. Dark brown with a medium tan head 
.Coffee and malty tones. Malt, coffee,hops and bitterness. Medium body with a nice bitter/ roasted finish.

Draft. Pours a medium, well retained, ivory head, with minimal lacing, over a clear, light brown (SRM 19) body......nose is light chocolate from the roasted malts, heavy coffee, mild toffee/caramel. minimal hops.......taste is heavy coffee, no toffee/caramel, hints of malts, finsihing with heavy burnt coffee bitterness, with midl hops.......mouth feel, medium body, slight alcohol, moderate carbonation. This misses the Brown Ale style a lot because of the total dominance of the heavy, overuse of the coffee beans. Less coffee, and more caramel/crystal would correct. BJCP 5/3/9/4/6

Can at home. It pours a dark amber reddish brown color with a foamy light tan head. The aroma has coffee with strong notes of toasted malt, some maple syrup and nuts. The flavor is pretty bitter with hints of syrup and coffee. The coffee character isnt very strong. Nutty malts and strong earthy/piney bitterness. Not really a big fan of this one.

473ml can from Boxbeers. Pours brown with a foamy thick head. Aroma of coffee beans, mild roastiness, chocolate and citrusy hops. Taste is smooth, slightly hoppy and roasty with some coffee beans, chocolate and hints of cocoa. Finish is smooth and slightly malty with some roastiness, coffee and hops. Okay.

Can. Pours dark golden/brown with a pretty tall white and frothy head which dies rather quickly. Aroma is dominated by coffee, though also some milk chocolate and citrus herbs. Lovely palate, quite light bodied though not watery. Medium carbonation. Shortish. Flavour is much like the aroma, bitterness from the coffee beans and sweetness from malty chocolate. This is a beer to spend time with.

1 pint can. Pours a dark brown with moderate head. Aromas of grass and fresh ground coffee. Flavors of same with additional dry citrus and roasted grain. Pretty much coffee though nice for what it is.

50 cl can from Boxbeers. Brown color with beigewhite head. A nutty fruity aroma at first, hazelnut, dark chocolate, raisin, malty, coffee, spices. Pretty heavy coffee bitterness, citrusy flavour. Light body with a bit creamy texture. Above average carbonation, flavours stay pretty long in the mouth. Not bad for a brown ale.
Can. Pours brown with medium off white head. Medium bodied, with a hint of spice on the backend. Notes of chocolate and coffee but nothing overwhelming. Very enjoyable.

Can to tulip
Consummation: Malts, bacon, oak and cedar
Adjunct: Wood chips, toasted malts, and bacon; hazy brown with no head
Can - Dark espresso notes, roasty and nice. Deep cloudy brown with a rich beige head. Nice roasty coffee and Chcolate and bitter notes. Nice.

Can.

A- Earthy coffee

A- Brown color, hazy liquid, beige head.

T- Coffee, earthy, slightly bitter.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, slightly bitter roasty finish.

O- After opening the can, I wasnt sure I was down with the vegetal coffee aroma. After letting it warm a bit I totally changed my mind. A lot of earthy coffee on the aroma and palate. Very solid brown ale. I think a touch of vanilla would take this to the next level.

Pours brown with a big tan head. Aroma is coffee, aluminum, slight bitter almond and biscuity. Taste is black coffee, with complementary bitterness, almonds, earthy, a mild bready maltiness. Somewhat thin, tinny mouthfeel. It's ok.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma is coffee, roasted malt, nuts, metallic. Appearance is dark brown, light brown head. Taste is nutty, roasted malt, metallic, coffee, robust. Mouthfeel is medium body, light carbonation, robust nutty metallic aftertaste. Overall, this is solid.
aroma of roasted nuts and coffee. flavor is nicely balanced between coffee, nuts, and some hopps. just crushable for a brown ale. pours deep brown with a tan head. had out of a can at home.

Can poured. Slightly hazy brown hue w/ a medium creamy beige head. Light nutty aromas. Initial flavor is light sweet w/ a light bitter finish. Tastes are almond skins, breakfast blend medium roast coffee and straw. Medium bodied.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sample, from a can. Murky brown color, with a big, foamy, creamy head. The aroma is roasted coffee, caramel, molasses, peat, and toasted oak. Sweet and roasty, with a sharp bitterness. Medium body, creamy, and a little astringent. This is a nice, aggressive brown ale. A little too much roast for my taste, but pretty good.

Evil Twins Wet Dream is a coffee-infused Brown Ale for early risers or an after dinner treat for those looking to bring on sweet dreams. Christ, they should pay me to write this shit for them. Mahogany pour with a creamy head. Huge notes of espresso with some malty richness in the background. Coffee-forward flavors of roasted beans and zesty citrus. Brown Ale is usually a fairly reserved style, but the coffee gives this brew some bright bitterness. No other beverage named after nocturnal emissions has ever been so appealing.
16 oz tall boy. Light brown pour with a thin off white head. Aroma of coffee, caramel, earthy malt, nutmeg, and faint smoke. Medium body, nice brew.

This is a complex brown ale with a lot going on. Throughout the glass new notes continued showing up on the nose and the tongue, and I never quite felt like Id totally figured it out. It pours copper/brown with average head and average carbonation. The aroma combines honey, coffee, citrus, a little bit of nutmeg... and the flavor is at turns sweet, rich, and sometimes bitter. A little bit of boozy vapor and coffee comes through in the finish. Really nice beer.

16 ounce can into pint glass; Batch #001, no can dating. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy reddish brown color with a 2 finger fairly dense and fluffy khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of caramel, brown sugar, medium roast coffee, brown bread, toasted biscuit, grapefruit, lemon, orange, pine, light pepper, light chocolate/nuttiness, and herbal/toasted earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance and and complexity of dark/bready malt, coffee, and moderate citrus/earthy hop notes; with solid strength. Taste of caramel, brown sugar, medium roast coffee, brown bread, toasted biscuit, grapefruit, lemon, orange, pine, light pepper, light chocolate/nuttiness, and herbal/toasted earthiness. Moderate pine, herbal, spicy, citrus rind bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, brown sugar, coffee, brown bread, toasted biscuit, lemon/orange rind, pine, and herbal/toasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt, coffee, and moderate citrus/earthy hop flavors; with a nice malt/bitterness balance, and minimal astringent hop flavors after the finish. Light-moderate dryness from bitterness, increasing through the glass. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth and moderately creamy/bready/sticky balanced mouthfeel that is nice; becoming lightly resinous near the end of the glass. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 6%. Overall this is a very good American brown ale. All around good complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt, coffee, and moderate citrus/earthy hop flavors; very smooth and easy to drink. This was definitely hoppier than I expected given the coffee aspect, I would have expected more focus on the malt flavors to compliment the coffee. It was still very enjoyable and nicely balanced.
On tap at TJs. Poured a brown color with a small sized off white head. Roast, coffee, caramel, chocolate, and some nuttiness.

Smells of light roasted malts sweet delectable coffee, marshmallow, and some floral scents. Really nice medium brown color with three finger tan head, great lacing. Taste of sweet roasted malts, super robust coffee and bitter semi sweet chocolates. Full body that tends to coat the tougue with rightous carbonation for this style of beer. Love the great complexity of this brew on taste and smell. This brew gets much love from me. Great beer!

Sampled on draft at 3R6P this beer poured a nut brown color with light orange highlights and a medium sized creamy off white head that left good lacing. The aroma was faint but roasty, woody and had a bit of fruit. The flavor was bitter, roasty and woody with a coffee note. Medium length finish. Medium body. Meh.

Brown sugar, caramel, toffee, and tootsie roll aromas; light grapefruit and earthy hops too. Taste is red grapefruit, brown sugar, caramel and toffee. Berries and earthy hops kick in the finish. An after taste of grapefruit and earthy hops.

Purchased a 12 oz. bottle at 7 Eleven, Kittery, ME. Dark brown in color, thin head. Aroma consists of crushed nuts, dry coffee notes, and light chocolate notes also showing. 
The flavor is the aroma, decent level of coffee. The body is on the thin side (yes, it is a Brown ale and not a Stout) yet, to me it is thin. Its a good beer but Im not sure why everybody is so impressed with this.

Can. Brown with one finger head. Lots of roast, slightly nutty. Dark chocolate notes with plenty of bitter coffee and hops. Quite dry. Seems like coffee is the new trendy addition. Im ready to move on.

Brown pour with a thick foamy light beige head. Thick roasty nose with earthy toasted brown malt and a roasty bit of slightly burnt coffee. Slightly burnt brown malt flavor with a light bit of coffee and a slightly burnt tone to it.
473ml can. This is actually some god stuff, good fresh non-green peppery coffee flavor.
Great brown ale. Espresso, but of vanilla and a nice citrus hop. Fresh and rich with a great balance. The roast is in perfect balance!

Tallboy can from Savor Growl: amber-copper pour with frothy light tan head. aroma pleasant sweet malt, light coffee. tastes are bitter cocoa, coffee, lightly sweet, herbal, spice. very creamy palate. interesting.
Pours a mahogany color with an off-white head. Aroma is lots of coffee and some earthy hops. Flavor lots of coffee with chocolate and earthy hops. Surprisingly bitter. Pretty good.

Pint can into a pint glass. Pours a deep brown, with a dense medium sized tan head. Nose is coffee and grassy hops. Taste is nutty, malty. Hop bitterness on the finish, with coffee in the middle. Not bad.

Dark brown colored. Dense light brown head. Aroma. Caramel, coffee, Brown sugar, sweetness. Flavor. Roast, Caramel, marzipan Loads of coffee, herbs, sweetness, light liqourice. Medium to full bodied. Ends caramelly and coffeeish.

Can pour cola brown with moderate ecru head. Nose nice big roasted coffee and some dark chocolate. Taste light bitter up front, then nice coffee, slight nut, mild woody, milk chocolate and moderated roasted malt. mixed chocolate and roast in the finish. I like coffee beers.
Nuts, coffee, pine bitterness and citrus with a hint of chocolate. Interesting combo, but it works in this brown ale.

Bottle. Pours a clear and dark brown beer with an off white head. The aroma is malt, roasted, chocolate, coffee and hops with citrus. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness. Overall a good beer.
Drank from a tall boy can, purchased in Warwick, NY while playing disco golf! A good solid brown ale.

(Bottle) Dark brown colour with dense, beige head. Malty, roasted nose with notes of dark bread, coffee, caramel, roasted malt and citrus peel. Malty, roasted taste with coffee, dark bread, dark chocolate, roasted malt, grapefruit, pine needles, tropical fruit and a generous citric/coffee bitterness in the finish. Medium body, quite dry. Tasty brown ale, drawing in the porter direction, with generous amounts of coffee and citric hops. Very nice.
Pours dark brown with a foamy brown top. Aroma is rich nutty and mocha. Taste is velvet mouthfeel, nutty, coffee and mocha. Very rich and delicate.

Pours a deep cola red with two fingers of loose tan head diminishing rapidly to a thin skim, moderate lacing. Nose is roasted nutty malt, coffee, light pine resin and citrus, hints of chocolate. Taste follows suit, with a bitter finish. Medium body with low carbonation and a creamy mouth feel.

Not a bad brown ale at all. Nearly a coffee porter or stout with the darkness of the malt, but with a somewhat lighter body. Im not sure how old this bottle was (come on folks, is it that hard to put a damn bottling date on the label?) but I have a suspicion that the hops were a little muted with age - Id like to try this fresh or on tap and see if theres a bit more hop presence.
Bottled:Pours dark brown with a mid sized, creamy head.Aroma is dark chocolate and toffee.Smooth mouth feel.Taste is toffee, chocolate and some licorice. Bitter finish.
Bottle at home. Pours brown, light coffee roast, dry toffee, bitter roast, chocolate.
Draft, pours dark brown with beige head. Aroma is sweet with dried fruits, coffee and liquorice. Flavour is sweet, with coffee dominating the flavour. Very nice beer
Mycket trevlig doft tung ändå frisk kaffetoner.. Lagom torr å smakar mycket balanserat . Yess riktigt bra. Coffie Collective ihop mer amerikanskt bryggeri kan ju ej misslyckas..

Bottle, pours a dark amber brown with a small beige head. Aroma brings out old hops, bready malt, and some light toffee - weird stuff. Flavour brings out fairly astringent hops, bready malt, and some oxidation. Seems off - not very interesting.

On tap @ Henrik, Bergen. Deep brown, near-black body with a large creamy off-white head. Nose is brown malts, grainy cereal tones, chocolate and hints of dark chocolate. Taste is roasted grains, strong espresso, dark chocolate and hints of ashes and bitter herbs. Medium to light body, medium carbonation. A bit heavy on the espresso factor compared to the overall body and taste profile, but pretty nice nevertheless.

Bottled. Pours deep brown with a lacing, beigehead. Aroma of citrus notes, roasted malt, nuts and coffee. Sweet flavor that ends up dry and pleasant bitter. Medium bodied, oily texture and average carb. An excellent brown.
nutty, coffe and caramel aromas, Pour dark brown with a tan white head. Mellow sweet and bitter taste. a great creamy mouthfeel with a fine carbonation
Tap. Brown in color with tan head. Mild aroma of caramel, hops and bread. Taste of malt, caramel and a bit of saltiness. Medium bodied and delicious beer.

This a drinker hop,malts and a nutty flavor that for a liter beer ligers on the plate. Dark chocolate color with a deep tan head. Aroma is sweet,coffee and mocha with nothing left to the finsh then hops.
De botella. Más que una Brown parece una porter. Dulzona y cafetosa. Agradable caramelo, con un poco de alcohol acabando seca.

Sample from bottle @sbwf13. Dark reddish brown with beige head. Aroma is vinous, alcohol, roasted, chocolate, coffee and dried fruit. Taste is similar, sharp, roasted, vinous, a bit burnt, chocolate and dried fruits

Pours a dark brown with a brown head. Aroma has some nice roasted malts - a bit salty liquorice and some coffee notes. On the sweeter side I get some syrup and some brown sugar. Balance is nice and this is a well smelling brown ale. The taste has a lot of the characteristics from the aroma but with some nutty caramel - toffee like sweetness added. The more roasted liquorice notes is also delicious here. Very nice brown ale!

50 cl. bottle. Dark brown colour with a small, dense tan head. Light roasted aroma with citrus, grasses, mocha, rich, dark chocolate and caramel malts. Taste is light sweet. Full body - rather rich for a 6,9 % alc. - creamy texture and a soft carbonation. Long lasting bitter and dry finish with roasted malts coffee and dark chocolate. Excellent Brown Ale.
[10/6/13] Draught at CASK Pub & Kitchen in London. Black. Roasty aroma with coffee, some chocolate and some hops. Roasty and coffee-ish flavor with some hoppy bitterness. Medium-bodied.
Tap at Crowbar. Black with beige head. Citrus and espresso nose. Good roasted bitterness, refreshing citrus, hints of chocolate towards the finish. Nice piece.

Bottle from Coppers, Newcastle. This very dark brown-black beer pours with a very thin wisp of tan coloured head. It has dark chocolate, liquorice, blackcurrant and coffee flavours with a creamy fruity and coffee finish. Excellent!

Keg at CBC. Nose of coffee, caramel, alcohol. Brown-orange with a lacy head. Sweet caramel flavor, coconut, vanilla, coffee. Silky and full, not too heavy, with a very bitter finish. Good but not for me.

On tap at Crowbar. Dark brown with a reddish hue and a small, beige head. Roasty aroma with chocolate, coffee, dark dried fruits and hops. Moderate sweet with a quite dry and pleasantly bitter finish. Nice one!

Keg at CBC Brixton. Very dark reddy/brown with a tan head. Aroma is mostly coffee, with a bit of sweetness. Medium body with medium carbonation. It's good, pretty light and the coffee, dark roastiness, the bitter choc don't hit you over the head but are nicely balanced and are leveled off with some sweetness. Nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The pours deep reddish brown with a tiny mocha head. The nose is roasted grain, some light chocolate and malty sweetness. The taste is more roasted grain, mild coffee, berry covered chocolate. Good stuff

Draft. A dark red beer with only a rim of tan head. The aroma has notes of hops, citrus fruits, and chhocolate. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, chocolate, coffee, citrus fruits, and hops, leading to a bitter finish.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is coffee, alcohol, roasted malt, hop. Flavour is coffee, alcohol, roasted malt, hop, caramel, chocolate. Full body. Nice beer.

Bottle @ Christers. Pours dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, nuts, chocolate. Flavor is malts, coffee, dark chocolate, nuts. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, lively carbonation, dry bitter finish. 100613

Bottle @ Aarhus tasting. Clear very dark brown with a big and lasting light brown head. Aroma is sweet, malty, roasted malt and coffee. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and roasted moderate bitter finish. 100613
Bottle. Very dark brown with big beige head. Aroma is malt, coffee, chocolate and caramel. Flavour is malt, caramel, coffee, chocolate, medium sweet, hop, little pine and bitter.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is rich roast malt, rich coffee, chocolate, licorice and hops
light roasted hoppy aroma,black, brown foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, soft carbonation, very bitter and hoppy aroma,

Bottle.

Dark brown with a white head. Aroma and taste of coffee, roasted malt, some chocolate and light hops. Rather soft and easy to drink. A descent one.

Pours an opaque dark brown with a huge initial tan head that slowly settles into a fair ring but leaves some good lace. Aroma is citrus, roasted malts, coffee, cocoa, and toffee. Flavour is coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malts, medium bitterness from the hops but I think also helped out from the dark malts, citrus, toffee, and finishes dry. Yet another good beer from evil twin.

Pours a clear dark brown with a moderate sized brown head. Aroma of citrus grassy hops, roasted malts & toffee. Taste is citrus and grassy hops, with a sharp bitterness, roasted malts, toffee, molasses and a nice dry finish. Excellent brown that finishes well.

Bottle. It pours a reddish dark brown body under a dense, finger-thick dark beige head. Lightly roasted malts, caramel, chocolate and some hoppy notes in the aroma. The flavor is rather strong for a brown ale, but pleasant. Quite coffee-ish in the flavor, roasted malts, chocolate and a nice bitterness and hoppy flavor. Full body, semi-dry and pleasantly carbonated. Lasting finish, dry and rather coffee-ish. Certainly a nice brown ale, wouldnt mind drinking more of this. 130420

Pours jet black with little or no head.

This tastes fairly bitter with some coffee notes.

This is fairly thin.

This tastes like a 6.9% beer.

Bottle, shared with Ian. Medium nut brown colour with a medium tan head that retains as a 3mm topping. Aroma is pleasant coffe, like a medium roast, with underlying sweet dark malts. The coffee sits center-stage, and really this beer depends on the quality of the coffee as much as anything else. Thankfully its very nice, slightly floral even. The supporting malts are tasty and in generous supply, and there is an appealing bready yeasty note that I really liked. Light acidity lends almost a tart quality to the finish (not quite tart). Great brew!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottled. Dark brown coloured. Dense light brown head. Aroma. Caramel, coffee, Brown sugar, sweetness. Flavour. Roast, Caramel, marzipan Loads of coffee, herbs, sweetness, light liqourice. Medium to full bodied. Ends caramelly  and coffeeish.
September 2011. Bottle. pours dark amber with a white head. While I can detect the citrus and the spice, the coffee beans dont blend in. Still a very nice ale.

Bottle at Borefts BF 2012, Bodegraven. Pours dark brown with a rich, beige froth of a head. Semi-dark malts in the nose with rich coffee of light acidity. Medium to big sweet flavor with robust coffee character, roasted malts, bitter chocolate. Medium bodied with average, creamy carbonation. Moderately sweet finish with dark malts, toasty sugars, light earth and coffee bitterness. Quite great balance and wonderful coffee character. A real winner.

Beautiful deep brown colour. Aroma is sweet malts with coffee in the background. Taste is very sweet with bitter coffee flavours at the tail-end. Perhaps the mouthfeel is too oily for this particular style in my opinion. Also, it lacks complexity in the hops area. Overall though, very drinkable exponent of the style, but nothing on the complexity of the rogue hazelnut brown.

500ml bottle from Archive Beer Boutique. My first beer from this brewer and what a cracker it is.  Pours a thick deep brown colour with a load of thick brown foam, looks the goods. Smells great also with a big hit of coffee in the aroma. Awesome full flavour that saturates the mouth with joy. Long on the palate - wet dream indeed.
Roasty, smooth and malty already a winner for me add in a nice touch of coffee, brilliant.  This was just another nice tasty interesting easy to drink brown ale that went down extremely well.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2014 Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours near black with a small yellow head. Nice lacing. Nose shows bitter, earthy coffee beans, a little nutty, quite roasty. A touch of cocoa powder. Great bitter sweet stuff. Taste shows ever creamy coffee and milk chocolate. Not so mocha-like as the coffee is the big focus here. Massive winner for coffee fans. Rich and earthy. Creamy mouth feel with a long bitter finish. Really fantastic stuff

Large frothy tan coloured head mild medium carbonation very dark pour aromas sweet sugary caramel coffee nut crisp hops flavours lovely rich coffee taste good bean taste dry cocoa rich chocolate toffee caramel sweetness resiny touch hoppy fruit taste strong ibu from coffee taste the finish decent brown fruity hops good malt mix sweet bitter ending the accented coffee taste lasting bitter good
Bottle. Brown with tan head. Cold coffee aroma. Taste of cold pressed coffee with tootsie roll chocolate, like chocolate brownie, toffee. Smooth and sweet with a light bitter finish. Nice
Bottle @ home. Aroma is roasty malt, some herbal and floral hops, some chocolate notes. Flavour is roasty malt, bitter chocolate, molasses and bitter liquorice. Nice, but quite alcoholic.

Draft. Pours very dark brown with a red tint and a average beige head. 
Aroma is coffee, red berries, toasted malt, cocoa, orange, chocolate.
Taste is moderate sweet and bitter with a subtle acidic note. Body is medium, texture is creamy, carbonation is average. Finishes hoppy bitter.  Very atypical for the style, but I really like the beer.

500ml bottle pours a deep brown color with a 3 finger light brown head with great retention eventually leaving some sporadic lacing on the glass.  Aroma is roasted grains with citrus and coffee beans.  Taste is roasted grain and coffee bitterness with some chocolate and caramel malty sweetness, all nicely balanced.  Medium bodied with adequate carbonation.  A very well done brown ale, although leaning towards being a stout.  Highly recommended.

25-DEC-2012, bottle @Morten, from Fish & Beer.
Dark brown with high tan lacing head.
Aroma is chocolate and coffee.
Taste is burnt roast, coffee, malt, chocolate, and very hoppy. Creamy.
More like a black IPA. Not a brown ale in my book, but very fine.

Bottle 500ml. @ home.Clear dark brown colour with a large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, coffee, dusty coffe, moderate roasted and chocolate, moderate hoppy, grass. Initial flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter, finish flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and heavy bitter with a long duration, dark dark coffee (strong coffee, dusty hops, hoppy. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. Very good balanced work, Ryan ;-) [20120828]

Keg at craft beer co. Rich roasted coffee and chocolate on the nose. Quite bitter flavour but alongside mouthwatering latte milky coffee flavours and a sweet malt finish. A different take on coffee beer.
Keg at Craft Islington. Dark brown, golden head. Aroma beefy, brown and roasty, bit of smoke. Taste coffee, nice dark fruitiness too, roasty, pretty nice. Bit of bitterness. Pretty solid beer!

Draught:
Medium sized tan head on top of a dark blackish beer.
Smell malts, coffee, roast.
Taste coffee, roast, tabacco, bitters, roasted plants.
Aftertaste is roast, coffee, bitter, bitter plants and a light floral tone.
Low carbo, creamy mouthfeel, meeium to lightly fuller body and a creamy texture. Thats all I wrote down...
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: On tap @ Beer temple. Dark brown color. Beige head, sticky, good lace. Aromas: roasted malts, hops, citrus, coffee, fruity/acidic. Flavor is lightly sweet, roasted, medium bitter. Body is medium. Finishes roasted, coffee, bitter. Going more towards a stout.

50 cl bottle @ home. Pours dark brown with a little sediment and a tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and hops. Flavour is very similar to the aroma  with a slightly bitter finish.
On tap in Beer Temple. Poured a murky brown with a small tan head. Aroma of coffee and some malt. Flavour of berry fruit and alcohol with some caramel and coffee.

Roasted dusty coffee malty notes. Sweet Dreams i will call it. The sweetness is replaced by a pronounced bitterness from the malts or hops. Fine brew.
Pours a clear and dark brown beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, roasted, chocolate, coffee and hops with citrus. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness. Overall a good beer.
Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; Pours cloudy dark brown with an off white/tan head, roast malt and nut taste with a quite thick mouth feel, a slight taste of hop bitterness.

Dark brown hazy beer with huge tan head. Aroma of freshly ground coffee. Fresh light citrus notes with some toasty smell. Medium bodied, quite bitter with great fresh light dark taste. Might have a little more body but very good late night summer beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Color: dark black beer with medium brown foam. Smell: chocolate and coffee, roasted malt and caramel. Taste: roasted malt, caramel, rye. Aftertaste: rye, roasted malt

Dark brown coloured and clear. Has an off-white head, diminishing. Hoppy aroma, mixed with soy-sauce, dry coffee and faint chocolate. Flavor starts almost without sweetness, finish heavy bitter. Dry, watery texture and soft carbonation.

Draft @ Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen. Pours a dark brown color with a longlasting off-white head. Has a slightly roasted malty hoppy aroma with hints of caramel. Fruity malty hoppy caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty hoppy finish.

Draught @ John Bull Pub, Aalborg
Pours dark brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, chocolate, caramel, coffee and citrus. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter with a long chocolate, coffee and bitter finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

On [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Bull. Pours dark brown with an off-white head. Aroma of roasted and toasted malt, coffee, some caramel and licorice. Flavor is sweet and malty with some coffee, roasted grains, some bitterness and chocolate. Medium body, average carbonation.

Bottle sample @ Borefts 2012. The pours deep reddish brown with a tiny mocha head. The nose is roasted grain, some light chocolate and malty sweetness. The taste is more roasted grain, mild coffee, berry covered chocolate. Good stuff, supple body. Very drinkable.

Tap @ John Bull Pub Aalborg. Pours a really dark brown color with a beige head. Aroma is filled with nice bitter coffee notes, some almost juicy citrus and grassy hops, nutty notes, caramel and sweet malt. Flavor follows the nose with almost juicy hops again of citrus, grass and floral notes, with lots of bitter coffee, caramel, toasted malt and nutty notes. The body is on the lighter side of medium with a dry mouth feel. Overall a nice coffee flavored hopped up Brown Ale.

Bottle from itap. Brown a murky brown color with a nice big creamy tan head. Beer did leave some lacing on the glass as it went. Aroma was mild coffee, caramel, roasted malts and some vanilla. Flavor was milk chocolate,  vanilla, and roasted flavors. Rich and complex body. Medium mouthfeel. Drier roasted finish. Very good beer.

Pours dark brown with a creamy tanned head leaving laces. Aroma is sweet roasted fruity fidges some dark fruits smokey. Flavor very nice as aroma, good malty ess and roastyness accompanied with steady bitterness. Finishes longliver bitter roasted.
From bottle @ Borefts 2012. Coffee, caramel and red fruit in both aroma and flavor. The coffee is more pronounced in the flavor. Long coffee bitter finish. Somewhat sticky mouthfeel.

Botella. Deep dark brown colour, beige huge head, good lacing. Hoppy fruity and coffee caramel well toasted malty aroma. Good mouthfeel indeed. Flavour is sweet with plenty of well toasted caramela nd malt with coffee and some chocolate along with a good well lasting well above medium bitterness, dry like. Niiice.

Bottle in a hotel room in Utrecht.
Dark brown coloured with a small beige head.
Sweet and light roasted aroma of dark chocolate, hops and grass.
Light roasted flavour of dark chocolate, nuts, hops and grass.
Hoppy finish.
From a bottle at Borefts beer festival, de Molen, day two.  Pours black with a thin white head. Slight sourness but otherwise overwhelming coffee flavors. Bitter finish.

Bottle sampled @ Borefts 2012. Dark brown with a mocha head. Smell of sweet mocha, chocolate malts, cheaper gift chocolate, sweet spices, coffee. Taste is tad milky, mocha, cheaper gift chocolate in reasonable amounts, caramel, sweet spices, ok brown ale buried underneath, I get what they were aiming for but need to be fuller, I think, still falls a bit short, tad creamier body. Makes me think a bit of what soft dookie was all about.
Bottle at Boreft Beer Festival 12, Bodegraven: Dark brown coloured brew with taste of coffee and dry bitter finish. Not an Wet Dream but a Dry Dream insted.

Bottle at Borefts. Dark pour with a thin tan head and sticky lace. Malty aroma with a bitter malty liquorice flavour. A nice ale that was much appreciated, but not so different to similar beers brewed by many other breweries.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle sampled at Borefts.  Pours dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, slight lactose, wood and toffee.  Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter.  Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation.

bottle ... at de molen ... dark brown ... thin tan head ... soft coffee roast ... soft toffee ... chocolate malt ... bitter toffee roast ... soft toffe malt ... nice coffee linger ... but long bitter linger thats a little too  much for me.

Bottle, bought @ Fanø Bryghus. Pours deep brown that is almost black. Large creamy off-white head. Aroma has sweet caramel, light chocolate, firm roasted coffee. Medium to low carbonation, super lovely creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is sweet, malty, caramel, light chocolate, walnuts. The coffee is very prominent and firm, lending the beer and good dryness and mild bitterness. Splendid upgrade.

Draught at Ørsted Ølbar. Opaque dark dark brown, verging on black. Great foamy beige head. Hoppy nose with some molasses, roast, cocoa and grapefruit. Taste follows the aroma, with smooth coffee setting in alongside licorice notes. Medium sweet, dry, roasted heavy bitter finish. Very very OK.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle @ Odense tasting. Chestnut body with a medium offwhite head. Aroma is nuts, roast, malt, licorice. Flavor is hops, fruity, toffee. Nice.

On tap. Pours a hazy dark brown with a creamy beige head. Roasty and nutty aroma, quite fat. Rich body with a fairly good roast character but never burned. A distinct hopping if never particularly aromatic - leading to a bitter finish. Actually I dont really pick up any coffee, and to be honest thats fine with me. 180912

Dark chestnut with a big and lasting off-white head. Malty aroma of toffee and bread crust with a mild and elegant coffee note. Sweetish and rich flavour with equal parts coffee, toffee and hops - pine and herbal hops and a good intense bitterness
Bottle @ Odense September Tasting, 2012. Pours  dark brown with a creamy head. Coffee, mocha, roast and liquorice. Smooth and full bodied. Roasted bitter and hoppy finish.

Bottle at Theis and Mettes sour+ tasting. Pours a clear dark brown with an off-white head. Dry and bitter with a soft sweetness. Aromas of dark malts and some brown sugars. Medium bodied. Medium carbonation. Long bitter finish.
Bottle at home. Clear dark brown - offwhite head. Nutty, roasted, chocolate, fruity, aroma and taste of fresh coffee, cocoa, light burnes notes, nice full bodied, light bitterness. Lovely.

From tap at Dronning Louise. Pours hazy brown with a small tan head. Aroma is solid fruity, hoppy and light coffee note. Fruity, peachy and citrusy. Mild herbal coffee and slidgrapefri to peachy hoppy. Smooth fruity and bitter finish.
